_exec_summary.SummaryText:
he Clean Air Act.  Texas Instrument's RFAB facility has the following RMP-regulated substances:

	Hydrogen Chloride (anhydrous), CAS Number 7647-01-0
The Hydrogen Chloride (anhydrous) distribution systems at RFAB 1 and RFAB 2 consist of a 21,000-pound tube trailer provided by the chemical manufacturer, and associated gas cabinets, valve manifold boxes, piping, valves, and controls.  At RFAB 1 & 2 bulk yards, there are three storage bays for HCL, thus Maximum Intended Inventory (MII) of RFAB1 HCl is 84,000 pounds. For supply continuity purposes, additional HCl material up to 21,000 Ibs may periodically be staged outside of the R1 & R2 bulk chemical yard, while the maximum quantity (MII) of RFAB2 HCl is 63,000 lbs. The inventory consists of three tube trailers that hold 21,000 pounds each (one trailer online to the factory and two trailers in Auto Switch Ready/Standby). 
The maximum quantity in each "process" is greater than the EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 5,000 pounds listed in Appendix 1 of 40 CFR 68.130 and OSHA's PSM threshold quantity of 5,000 pounds listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119.

	Trichlorosilane, CAS Number 10025-78-2 
The Trichlorosilane distribution systems at RFAB 1 and RFAB 2 each consist of a 40,000-pound tube trailer provided by the chemical manufacturer, and associated gas cabinets, valve manifold boxes, piping, valves, and controls.  At RFAB 1 and RFAB 2 bulk chemical yards, there are two storage bays for TCS with a maximum storage of 80,000 pounds.  The maximum quantity in this "process" is greater than EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix 1 of 40 CFR 68.130 and OSHA's PSM threshold quantity of 5,000 pounds listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119.

	Hydrogen, CAS Number 1333-74-0 
The Hydrogen distribution systems at RFAB 1 gas plants consist of two 18,000-gallon liquid hydrogen storage tanks, two vaporizers, purifiers, and all associated piping and controls. The maximum quantity in each "process" is greate

Description of Texas Instrument's overall approach to chemical safety:

At Texas Instruments, we strive to maintain a culture and work environment free of illness or injury. Each employee is accountable for making that possible, regardless of their role. 

In our drive toward zero work-related injuries and illnesses and safe operations, we aim to: 
	Comply with applicable environmental, safety and health (ESH) laws and regulations. 
	Create and operate safe work sites. 
	Maintain proper environmental, safety, and health protocols and controls. 
	Design and build inherently safe buildings and systems and engineer out equipment risks. 
	Deliver relevantly and required ESH training. 
	Inspect and audit our processes to assess compliance with rigorous legal and customer requirements and our own stringent standards.

TI's broader approach to environmental stewardship is interdisciplinary and comprehensive. We have long aspired to the goal of "zero wasted resources," and this drive for efficiency helps reduce greenhouse gases and other air emissions as well as energy consumption, water use, and waste while increasing resource conservation and efficiency in all aspects of our operations. 

Our environmental, safety, and health (ESH) policy and principles guide our efforts to operate sustainably, from manufacturing conscientiously designed products to efficient product distribution, and from responsibly sourced materials to maintaining compliance with environmental regulatory requirements. 

TI manufacturing sites maintain an ESH management system that is both ISO14001:2015 & ISO45001:2018 compliant. Sites also complete an annual assessment of their environmental, safety, and health performance and use the results to help establish annual site objectives and targets. 

It is the responsibility of every employee to understand and support TI's ESH policy and principles. All employees globally receive ESH training on TI's programs to ensure their safety and health and co

ntribution to environmental stewardship. Employees receive additional relevant training and communications based on their roles and working environment. Contractors must also comply with TI's ESH standards.

Texas Instruments Environmental, Safety, and Health Policy: 
Texas Instruments Incorporated is committed to:
	Providing safe and healthy working conditions.
	Protecting the environment and preventing pollution
	Fulfilling applicable legal and other obligations.
	Eliminating hazards and reducing risks.
	Continually improving operations.

This commitment includes the involvement of leadership, consultation and participation of employees, and the setting and tracking of relevant objectives for TI operations.

Texas Instruments Environmental, Safety, and Health Principles: 
1.	Leadership and employee commitment and accountability: Employees at all job levels are held accountable for compliance with ESH requirements, and achievement of continual improvement objectives and targets appropriate to their function. TI makes environmental, safety, and health protection of our workers and the communities in which we operate a top priority. We embrace our responsibility and accountability for the outcomes of our operations. 
2.	Risk assessment of activities and processes: TI assesses in advance the potential impact of our activities on the safety and health of our employees and the environment. These assessments and actions to reduce and control ESH risks are ongoing aspects of our operating processes. Operations are conducted in compliance with applicable laws, regulations, and other requirements.
3.	Natural resources, water, and energy stewardship: TI's goal of zero wasted resources fosters the sustainable use of natural resources, the efficient use of water, energy, and raw materials, and the prevention of pollution. TI works to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in manufacturing processes and evaluates the impact of potential climate-related risks in business strategy,

planning, and operations to safeguard TI's long-term business resilience.
4.	Emergency preparedness: TI is prepared for emergencies that could impact our operations, the environment, or the safety and health of employees and communities in which we operate. Where feasible, TI works closely with local emergency agencies and provides leadership to assist our local communities to improve their emergency preparedness capabilities.
5.	Product stewardship: TI responsibly manages the potential impact of our products on human health and safety, and the environment through product life-cycle consideration and other activities. Our energy-saving product portfolio uses cutting-edge innovation to support our customers efforts to use resources in the most efficient way while mitigating climate impacts. TI complies with applicable product-related regulations and meets agreed-upon customer requirements.
6.	Supplier and contractor relationships: Long-standing partnerships with suppliers and contractors help ensure the suppliers' compliance with applicable regulations and TI ESH policies, standards, and specifications, including TI's Chemical and Material Control Specifications. We collaborate with our suppliers to provide the best solutions in order to meet material and regulatory requirements as well as best practices.
7.	Public information and influence on public policy: TI promotes an open dialogue with our workers and the communities in which we operate. We work constructively with governments, the scientific community, industry, and public interest groups to help develop sound laws, regulations, and guidelines for continuous improvement in environmental safety and health while promoting useful products and global competitiveness.

TI serves the world's most innovative electronics companies, helping them develop new ideas that change the way we live. We design and make semiconductors that we sell to electronics designers and manufacturers all over the world. Additionally, we

sell calculators and related products. 

Our analog, embedded processing, and wireless technologies permeate daily life in many different ways, from digital communications and entertainment to medical services, automotive systems, and wide-ranging applications in between. By providing semiconductor technologies that promote greater power efficiency, enable more features, enhance performance, and deliver more value, TI expands the possibilities every day for how we learn, connect, grow and discover.

RFAB, the world's first 300-mm analog wafer fab, located in Richardson, Texas is the world's first green, LEED-certified (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) semiconductor manufacturing facility. The LEED Green Building Rating System is a voluntary, consensus-based national rating system for developing high-performance, sustainable buildings. TI RFAB's administration and wafer fab buildings both achieved LEED Gold certification in 2008. The system, developed by the U.S. Green Building Council, assesses building practices in five areas - site development, water efficiency, energy and atmosphere, materials and resources, and indoor environmental quality. 

TI manufactures billions of integrated circuits (semiconductor chips) annually, which involves using large amounts of water, energy, and chemicals. Every year, RFAB produces thousands of analog chips. 

Producing world-class semiconductors involves the use of hazardous and nonhazardous chemicals and gases, which is why TI has stringent controls in place to manage them. We also continuously assess the potential environmental, safety, and health impacts of these materials as new scientific information becomes available and regulations are adopted. 

Chemical selection and screening: 
We screen all incoming chemicals before incorporating them into our semiconductor manufacturing processes. Screening includes a review of customer concerns and regulatory standards, in addition to any environmental, safety, and heal

th controls required for their use. TI also has restrictions and standards related to chemicals incorporated into supplier contracts. 

If concerns about a chemical or other material arise during review, the matter is elevated to a chemical and material review board staffed by company experts. If a chemical or material is thought to be necessary for manufacturing but still raises concerns, the company's manufacturing leaders review the issue; where appropriate, they authorize additional time and resources to seek a safer alternative, or implement more stringent use controls. 

Chemical-use policy and practices:
TI is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations for chemical use. For example, we:
	Prohibit the use of Class I and Class II ozone-depleting substances in manufacturing. 
	Prohibit the use of persistent organic pollutants as defined by the United Nations Environmental Program. 
	Prohibit chemicals on the Prior Informed Consent list under the Rotterdam Convention. 
	Support the mission and objectives of the Basel Convention (Annex I, II, III, and VIII), which addresses environmental protection through the proper management of used chemicals and materials. 
	Do not manufacture products that contain radioactive substances. 
	Select the lowest-risk chemicals for use whenever possible.

Chemical handling:
After we approve chemicals for use, we carefully manage their transport, distribution, and disposal. The basic goal of our chemical-safety program is to minimize human contact with all chemicals. We accomplish this in six ways: 
1.	Availability of information. We work closely with our chemical supply chain to ensure that employees and contractors have up-to-date usage and handling information. 
2.	Engineering controls and personal protective equipment. We provide engineering controls such as safety interlocks and ventilation to prevent employee exposure to chemicals. Employees who work with or near hazardous chemicals or gases in areas

without built-in engineering controls are required to wear personal protective equipment and understand how to properly use it. 
3.	Chemical dock operations. We tightly control and protect chemical deliveries and storage by asking chemical professionals to handle all chemicals at one central location per site. 
4.	Just-in-time purchasing. We implement inventory controls to reduce potential chemical storage risks while maintaining an appropriate supply. 
5.	Closed chemical delivery system. Our chemicals are automatically fed to work locations through a series of carefully constructed distribution systems with appropriate leak detection, ventilation, and abatement controls. We use double-walled piping and additional containment systems where needed.  
6.	Used chemical management. We minimize any amount of discharged chemicals through several protective measures, including wastewater treatment, wet scrubbers, thermal oxidizers, and absorbers. Where on-site treatment is not available, licensed disposal contractors recycle and reuse valuable materials or dispose of waste appropriately. 

In order to manufacture integrated circuits (semiconductor chips), RFAB uses various materials and chemicals including a chemical that is subject to the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in the Clean Air Act.  Our practice is to use the safest materials effective for manufacturing processes, and these materials have proven to be particularly effective. TI uses the same chemicals safely at our other manufacturing plant sites. And, we use state-of-the-art control measures in chemical handling and control processes to protect our employees and community and minimize environmental impact.

In accordance with 40 CFR Part 68, a facility that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process is subject to the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in t

r than the EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix 1 of 40 CFR 68.130 and OSHA's PSM threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119(a)(1)(ii).

	Anhydrous Ammonia, CAS Number 7664-41-7
The Anhydrous Ammonia distribution systems at RFAB 1 and RFAB 2 consist of one 12,000-gallon storage tank each, two redundant 50-kilowatt vaporizers for RFAB 1 and two reductant 80-kilowatt vaporizers for RFAB 2, a tanker slip with fill stand, an NH4OH generator in the Caustic Room, and all associated piping and controls at RFAB 1 and RFAB 2 bulk yards.  The maximum quantity in each "process" is greater than EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix 1 of 40 CFR 68.130 and OSHA's PSM threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119.

Since Hydrogen Chloride (anhydrous), Trichlorosilane, Anhydrous Ammonia, and Hydrogen are also regulated under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, TI has completed a Program 3 Prevention Program to comply with the RMP rule. 

TI is committed to preventing accidental releases of Hydrogen Chloride (anhydrous), Trichlorosilane, Anhydrous Ammonia, and Hydrogen.  These systems are designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with all applicable regulations. TI employees and contractors having duties related to the bulk systems are thoroughly trained on applicable tasks and procedures.  Additionally, TI maintains a written emergency response program and has trained emergency responders on-site to protect workers and public safety, as well as the environment.    

Hazard Analysis:
A formal Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is conducted to assess the upset conditions the equipment may present, the controls in place, and the adequacies of these controls to prevent events with high or catastrophic potential. 

Process Controls:
Numerous process controls have been include in the design and operation of the equipment associated with the chemical processes cove

red by the PSM/RMP Rule including, fenced site with controlled access, controlled and limited access to the bulk chemical storage area, closed circuit camera monitoring of the bulk chemical storage area, foam fire suppression system for Trichlorosilane which is automatically activated, water misting / vapor suppression system for HCl which is automatically activated, water misting / vapor suppression system for Anhydrous Ammonia which is automatically or manually activated, UVIR fire sensors and area chlorine and ammonia monitoring devices, emergency exits with panic hardware, lightning protection and building reference ground protects the facility from lightning and static discharge, trailer Bays each equipped with trailer ground and tie down points, 24/7 supervised fire alarm panel, spill containment to contain the quantity of stored liquid and fire water, all fittings (valves, connections, etc.) on chemical container and lines are in an exhausted enclosure, exhausted enclosures are continuously monitored for leaks; any detection will automatically send warnings to operations for action, detection above ½ of the establish safety level will automatically shut down the supply system, exhaust scrubber at the bulk chemical storage area, written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), safe work practices and training for employees who operate and maintain the bulk chemical storage area, and trained onsite emergency responders.     

Operating Procedures:
TI RFAB maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and normal shutdown.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process. 

Employee Training:
All employees involved in operating and maintaining chemical processes covered by the PSM/RMP Rule, including supervisors and managers, and temporary or intermittent worker

s are provided initial training before their work on the covered process begins as well as refresher training.

Maintenance Activities:
TI RFAB maintains written procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.  Equipment associated with the chemical processes covered by the PSM/RMP Rule are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure the safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

The five-year accident history:
No incidents or releases have occurred involving the managed substances.  Incidents involving substances managed in regard to PSM/RMP requirements will be promptly investigated and reported in accordance with regulatory requirements.
 
The emergency response program:
TI maintains a written emergency response program and trained emergency responders to protect workers and public safety, as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including:
	Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures,
	Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,
	Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs,
	Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements, and
	Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.
TI has coordinated emergency response efforts with local emergency responders (fire departments, LEPC, etc.) and has provided training to facilitate an understanding of the regulated chemicals and process.    

The emergency response program is updated, when necessary, based on modifications made to facility processes.  

Planned changes to improve safety:
On-going programs, such as process hazard analysis re-evaluations, internal and external compliance audits, and training, continually aim to improve process safety.  TI RFAB maintains an ESH management sy

stem that is certified to both ISO14001:2015 & ISO45001:2018. This ensures the implementation of a successful safety and environmental management program that includes most of the elements required under the RMP and PSM rules throughout the entire plant.
